Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CI-EN: Trust-Hub: Development of Benchmarks, Metrics, and Validation Platforms for Hardware Security, and a Web-based Dissemination Portal

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The growing hardware security community is faced with an immediate need to develop effective tools and benchmarks. The purpose of this project is to lead a community-wide movement toward stronger assurances in our integrated circuits, computational platforms, and electronics supply chain. Based on the proven effectiveness of information sharing in many communities including crypto and computer-aided design, the PIs plan a significant enhancement and increase in scope of Trust-Hub, a central web-based repository for benchmarks, hardware authentication platforms, evaluation software, source codes, tools, and much more in the area of hardware security and trust.

The intellectual merits of this project include development of (i) procedures to dynamically generate trust benchmarks with hard-to-detect Trojan instances, (ii) hardware platforms for security validation, (iii) a suite of security metrics, (iv) a suite of ready to apply attacks, and (viii) comprehensive hardware/software validation test suites and data. The results of this project would be of interest to semiconductor companies, US government agencies and university researchers worldwide. Benefits to the society include secure and trustworthy electronics for healthcare, defense, finance, transportation, automotive and other applications. This research will impact the education of students, industry professionals, and government agencies' engineers through courses, online materials, and on- and off-campus seminars.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Trust-Hub is a central web-based information repository for electronic IC and electronic supply chain security including benchmarks, validation, verification and evaluation software, source codes for attack and defense tools, and a venue for competitions for a range of hardware-based attacks in the area of hardware security and trust.  Results of this project are used by semiconductor companies, US government agencies and university researchers worldwide to make advances in the electronics supply chain security.  For instance, the benchmarks are used to self-report the strengths of defenses being developed by this community. This includes defenses against hardware Trojans, counterfeit ICs, intellectual property piracy and theft, reverse engineering and unauthorized overproduction of ICs.  The embedded security challenges pioneered as part of this project used a crowd sourcing-based based approach to red-team the developed defenses. For example, the logic locking competition has assessed the strength of combinational and sequential function locking defenses. The HACK@DAC sequence of competitions that grew out of this project is helping uncover exploitable bugs in processors. The project has helped develop security metrics to assess the security strengths of the developed  defenses. Overall, the Trust-Hub project continues to improve the security strength of the defenses that are deployed at various stages in the global electronics supply chain. This project has impacted the education of students, industry professionals globally, and government agencies' engineers through courses, online materials, and by participation in the competitions. Most importantly, the project has coalesced and sustained a worldwide community of researchers and practitioners in electronics supply chain security. Benefits to the society include secure and trustworthy electronics for healthcare, defense, finance, transportation, automotive and other applications.
